importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication marks the day when demolition of part of the East Wing officially began, signaling the start of a major White House construction project.
The project was first announced in July 2025, with Trump stating the ballroom would not interfere with the main structure and would be privately funded.
Site preparation work, including tree clearing, began in September 2025, preceding the actual demolition and construction phase.
The project is targeted for completion before the end of President Trump's term in January 2029, indicating a long-term timeline for the construction.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The construction period spans from the start of demolition in October 2025 through completion before the end of Trump's presidential term in January 2029.

keyTakeAways: The White House began demolishing part of the East Wing in October 2025 to build a $250 million ballroom for President Trump.
The demolition is underway without approval from the National Capital Planning Commission, which typically oversees major renovations to federal buildings.
The new ballroom will be 90,000 square feet and glass-walled, capable of accommodating up to 999 people, a significant expansion from the original 200-person East Room.
The White House claims the project is privately funded and will not cost taxpayers, with contributions from 'Patriots, Great American Companies,' and Trump personally.
Carrier Global Corp. has donated an energy-efficient HVAC system for the ballroom, confirming a major private-sector partnership.
The East Wing, built in 1902 and renovated in 1942, will undergo temporary relocation of offices and modernization during construction.
Trump insists that the ballroom respects the original structure and is needed to host dignitaries beyond the South Lawn pavilions.
No formal approval or public disclosure of donor identities has been made as of the article's publication date.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The White House began demolishing part of the East Wing in October 2025 to construct a $250 million, 90,000-square-foot glass-walled ballroom for President Donald Trump, despite lacking formal approval from the National Capital Planning Commission. The project, which was first announced in July 2025, is claimed to be privately funded with contributions from businesses and individuals, including a donation from Carrier Global Corp. for HVAC systems. While the White House asserts that offices in the East Wing will be temporarily relocated and the existing building is respected, the demolition raises concerns about federal oversight, historical preservation, and procedural compliance. The ballroom, designed to seat up to 999 people, is intended to replace the small East Room and allow for larger events, including hosting international dignitaries without relying on South Lawn pavilions. title: The White House Starts Demolishing Part of the East Wing to Build Trump's Ballroom
